It also recognises five different types of infinity: infinite in one and two directions, infinite in area, infinite everywhere, and infinite perpetually.", "importance": 30888.5, "date_string": "c. 400 BC"}, {"date": -400, "content": "Indian texts use the Sanskrit word \u201cShunya\u201d to refer to the concept of \u2018void\u2019 (zero).", "importance": 72726.5, "date_string": "4th century BC"}, {"date": -500, "content": "Indian grammarian P\u0101nini writes the Astadhyayi, which contains the use of metarules, transformations and recursions, originally for the purpose of systematizing the grammar of Sanskrit.", "importance": 43376.0, "date_string": "c. 500 BC"}, {"date": -500, "content": "Hippocrates of Chios utilizes lunes in an attempt to square the circle.", "importance": 11034.666666666666, "date_string": "5th century BC"}, {"date": -500, "content": "Apastamba, author of the Apastamba Sulba Sutra, another Vedic Sanskrit geometric text, makes an attempt at squaring the circle and also calculates the square root of 2 correct to five decimal places.", "importance": 3010.0, "date_string": "5th century BC"}, {"date": -530, "content": "Pythagoras studies propositional geometry and vibrating lyre strings; his group also discovers the irrationality of the square root of two.", "importance": 36371.0, "date_string": "530 BC"}, {"date": -600, "content": "the other Vedic \u201cSulba Sutras\u201d (\u201crule of chords\u201d in Sanskrit) use Pythagorean triples, contain of a number of geometrical proofs, and approximate \u03c0 at 3.16.
second half of 1st millennium BC \u2014 The Lo Shu Square, the unique normal magic square of order three, was discovered in China.", "importance": 60730.4, "date_string": "c. 600 BC"}, {"date": -800, "content": "the Yajur Veda, one of the four Hindu Vedas, contains the earliest concept of infinity, and states that \u201cif you remove a part from infinity or add a part to infinity, still what remains is infinity.\u201d", "importance": 28233.25, "date_string": "c. 8th century BC"}, {"date": -800, "content": "Baudhayana, author of the Baudhayana Sulba Sutra, a Vedic Sanskrit geometric text, contains quadratic equations, and calculates the square root of two correctly to five decimal places.
early 6th century BC \u2014 Thales of Miletus has various theorems attributed to him.", "importance": 30091.5, "date_string": "800 BC"}, {"date": -1000, "content": "Vulgar fractions used by the Egyptians. However, only unit fractions are used (i.e., those with 1 as the numerator) and interpolation tables are used to approximate the values of the other fractions.[6]
first half of 1st millennium BC \u2014 Vedic India \u2014 Yajnavalkya, in his Shatapatha Brahmana, describes the motions of the sun and the moon, and advances a 95-year cycle to synchronize the motions of the sun and the moon.", "importance": 32809.166666666664, "date_string": "c. 1000 BC"}, {"date": -1046, "content": "Chou Pei Suan Ching, the oldest Chinese mathematical text, is written", "importance": 1797.0, "date_string": "1046 BC to 256 BC"}, {"date": -1650, "content": "Rhind Mathematical Papyrus, copy of a lost scroll from around 1850 BC, the scribe Ahmes presents one of the first known approximate values of \u03c0 at 3.16, the first attempt at squaring the circle, earliest known use of a sort of cotangent, and knowledge of solving first order linear equations.", "importance": 25435.75, "date_string": "1650 BC"}, {"date": -1800, "content": "Moscow Mathematical Papyrus, findings volume of a frustum.", "importance": 9644.5, "date_string": "1800 BC"}, {"date": -1800, "content": "Berlin papyrus 6619 (19th dynasty) contains a quadratic equation and its solution.[5]", "importance": 0, "date_string": "c. 1800 BC"}, {"date": -2000, "content": "Mesopotamia, the Babylonians use a base-60 positional numeral system, and compute the first known approximate value of \u03c0 at 3.125.", "importance": 84521.0, "date_string": "c. 2000 BC"}, {"date": -2000, "content": "Scotland, Carved Stone Balls exhibit a variety of symmetries including all of the symmetries of Platonic solids.", "importance": 26597.0, "date_string": "c. 2000 BC"}, {"date": -2400, "content": "Egypt, precise astronomical calendar, used even in the Middle Ages for its mathematical regularity.", "importance": 85849.5, "date_string": "2400 BC"}, {"date": -2700, "content": "Egypt, precision surveying.", "importance": 40149.0, "date_string": "2700 BC"}, {"date": -2800, "content": "Indus Valley Civilization on the Indian subcontinent, earliest use of decimal ratios in a uniform system of ancient weights and measures, the smallest unit of measurement used is 1.704 millimetres and the smallest unit of mass used is 28\u00a0grams.", "importance": 53719.0, "date_string": "c. 2800 BC"}, {"date": -3100, "content": "Egypt, earliest known decimal system allows indefinite counting by way of introducing new symbols.[5]", "importance": 84555.5, "date_string": "c. 3100 BC"}, {"date": -3400, "content": "Mesopotamia, the Sumerians invent the first numeral system, and a system of weights and measures.", "importance": 38872.25, "date_string": "c. 3400 BC"}, {"date": -20000, "content": "Nile Valley, Ishango Bone: possibly the earliest reference to prime numbers and Egyptian multiplication.", "importance": 37470.25, "date_string": "c. 20,000 BC"}, {"date": -35000, "content": "Africa and France, earliest known prehistoric attempts to quantify time.[2][3][4]", "importance": 26940.0, "date_string": "ca. 35,000 BC to 20,000 BC"}, {"date": -70000, "content": "South Africa, ochre rocks adorned with scratched geometric patterns.[1]", "importance": 34009.0, "date_string": "ca. 70,000 BC"}]
